title: From two-dollar shops to $280m e-tailer for New Aim founders
text:
Few have heard of New Aim, which Mr Lam and Mr Liu started as university graduates in 2005, because most of its 4000 different product lines have hitherto been generically branded, and sold through other people’s portals.

Fung Lam, left, and Werner Liu at their then sole warehouse in Melbourne's Kensington in 2013. Enrique Ascuii

Nearly half of New Aim’s 2018-19 revenue of $180 million was sourced from its eBay department store, where it trades as OzPlaza and sells everything from mattresses and flatpack furniture to chainsaws and toys, Last year it became one of only 83 eBay sellers globally to have received more than 1 million pieces of customer feedback on the platform, 99.4 per cent of them positive.

A further significant piece of New Aim’s revenue was sourced via Catch Of The Day’s marketplace, where its store is known as Dailyplay.

Bigger than Catch

Yet the background seller is actually bigger than Catch. The Leibovich brothers’ e-commerce group recorded earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation of $17.4 million in the final year before its imminent sale to Wesfarmers, while New Aim’s EBITDA was $20 million.

Catch’s price tag of $230 million implied a historic EBITDA multiple of approximately 13 times, which if applied to New Aim would value it at about $260 million.

However a higher multiple could be justifiable to value New Aim’s founders when the Young Rich List is published in The Australian Financial Review Magazine on October 25. Listed local comparables JB Hi-Fi and Kogan are currently trading around price/earnings ratios of 14 times and 32 times respectively.

Advertisement

The founders said they had achieved compound annual revenue growth of 44 per cent over the past four years.

New Aim has always been profitable, which Mr Lam attributed in part to a trusted, long-term relationship with a third-party agent in China.

“We have 350 different manufacturers supplying us so it would be difficult to control that ourselves,” Mr Lam said.

The agent identifies trending products, validates demand for them using eBay’s subscription data platform Terapeak, then inspects samples of them as New Aim’s finance team performs a credit check on the manufacturer.

If successful, New Aim then orders three months’ worth of projected sales, as an expression of loyalty that Mr Liu said usually later resulted in the supplier offering him the best prices.

Diverse approach

The diversity that New Aim pursues among its suppliers and retail sales channels extends to its delivery partners, with the founders saying they work with “all of them” from Australia Post down. An internal algorithm determines which courier is best for each delivery.

From renting 11,000 square metres in a single warehouse in 2013, New Aim today rents 55,000 square metres across five warehouses in Melbourne.

Advertisement

Most of its 70 staff today either work there or in its customer service centre.

However, Mr Liu said new hires were being made to support a renewed effort to market the brands New Aim has created for some of its product categories, such as Giselle Bedding and Artiss Furnishings.

“We need to do more to differentiate from our competitors, because there are more of them all the time,” he said.

“Australia is still at high single digits for e-commerce’s share of total retail, where markets like the US have settled at 15 per cent, so there’s plenty of years of strong growth opportunity to come.”

Mr Lam, a bachelor of information technology from Monash University, and Mr Liu, a bachelor of commerce from Melbourne University, met at a mutual friend’s barbecue shortly after graduating and began buying selected items in bulk from two-dollar shops and reselling them on eBay.

“You have to start somewhere,” Mr Lam said.
description: Werner Liu and Fung Lam started out scouring shelves for stuff to re-sell on eBay, now they are headed for the Young Rich List.
